climbs.name: West Face Standard
climbs.fa: John Carey, Mart Chamberlain, Fred Thieme, Byron Ward

content.description: The original route to the summit, and still the most  popular.
content.protection: Standard rack, doubles of camalot .5-2 are helpful.

content.description: Pitch 1 climb the flakes to the ledge below the off-width chimney pitch.  This ledge has a dead tree on it and makes an excellent belay for the crux pitch 2.  The chimney is excellent with mostly stemming but some jamming the off-width.  Just warning that this is old school 5.9 and very strenuous for the grade.  However pro is good with large pieces low and options on the left side for smaller gear middle and up.  Exit the chimney and move left on excellent ledge for belay.  Pitch 3 is a fun crack, flake, block climb 5.8 with good pro.  Move into the crack off the belay ledge was the hard part, after which it eases.  Move up and left before a committing move out from under a small roof and your done.
content.protection: Standard rack of cams and nuts up to #5.  Had doubles in the mid-range cams.  Used all the large gear on pitch 2.  No cracks for top anchor on pitch 3, just large blocks, so bring long cordelette/slings.
content.location:
The route is the obvious vertical corner/chimney located in the middle of the West Face.  Start is just right of the Standard Route on Cl 3 ledges.

Descend via bolted anchors on the rappel chimney route.

content.description: The South Nose exit is a popular way to top out Chimney Rock. Several routes will get you to the S Nose. “It Ain’t Hay” is probably the most popular route to gain the S. Nose. From the belay ledge (gear anchor) identify a single bolt on a clean face. Plug a couple small pieces of gear and then make some delicate moves to get to the bolt. Continue up easier terrain to a two bolt anchor at a ledge. Unrope here and scramble to the summit or do another short pitch. There used to be a large block and a piton, that protected one more difficult move. No idea when this block fell (sometime after 2017).
content.protection: Single rack of cams and stoppers

content.description: Good movement up a well protected series of cracks.  Would be a lot better if there was less lichen.  The flare is wide and strenous and would be a considerable challenge to the 5.9 leader.  Easily done in one pitch if rope drag is managed.
content.location: There is a prominent rock thumb on the middle of the West face.  Work your way up face moves and a short handcrack until you pass the thumb.  Continue straight up until you reach some rap rings and the base of a flared slot.  Fire the slot and head up until you reach the prominent ledge below Fun Roof.  Finish via any of the roof pitches or walk off right.

content.description: Pitch one is a steep and interesting pitch with abundant protection possibilities.  Pitch two is the 5.9+ crux with some tough liebacking. A short third pitch goes to the summit.
content.protection: Full rack plus some big gear... multiple #4 Camalots are ideal.
content.location: Left side of the West Face.  Refer to any guidebook covering Chimney Rock for more details.

content.description:
This great route provides the second easiest line to Chimney Rock's summit.  You only briefly climb the actual "rappel chimney".

p1) easy 4th/5th climbing turns into awkward climbing as you near the belay ledge above a large right facing corner (2 wide cracks up the left side of the corner help identify the target ledge).  Belay at the large ledge just right of a rappel station.

p2-3) the routes crux, is a nice short crack leaving the belay ledge leading to a bulge. Pull through the bulge or step right at the bulge for an easy exit.  Belay at the 2-bolt anchor just 30' above or continue by stepping right into a great open book feature.  Follow the open book, with great pro opportunities to its end.  Move left into the belay/rappel notch. Belay here, then a short pitch leads to the summit.
content.protection: small rack to 2 inches, several slings
content.location: lookers left of the standard route, the general line climbs just right of the large right facing corner system which dominates the west faces left side

content.description: Starts from the belay ledge above "It Ain't Hay".  Follow the dihedral crack system on the left to the large ceiling overhead.  Work the crack in the ceiling with a series of hand and fist jams to the crux which is pulling around the roof.  There are good hands just around the corner of the roof.  Then follow the easy crack/flake to the top.
content.protection: Trad; doubles to 3" and bring lots of slings to limit rope drag.
content.location: The large roof above the belay ledge for "It Ain't Hay".

content.description: Start off on the right facing flake (I thought the crux was near the top of the flake)and work your way up around the right side of the thumb.  Stem up behind the thumb to a belay ledge just above.
content.location: Just to the right of the middle of the West Face on a right facing flake system.
